itemLabel: Sir William Parker, 1st Baronet, of Harburn

wikipedia_page.main: Admiral Sir William Parker, 1st Baronet (1 January 1743 – 31 October 1802), was a British naval commander.

response: * January 1 – Sir William Parker, 1st Baronet, of Harburn, British admiral (d. 1802)
* October 31 – Sir William Parker, 1st Baronet, of Harburn, British admiral (b. 1743)
* Rear-Admiral Sir William Parker, 1st Baronet, of Harburn (Hornblower and the Hotspur)
* Sir William Parker, 1st Baronet, of Harburn (1743–1802), British admiral

Schreiber was born in Bradwell-on-Sea, Essex, England to the Reverend Thomas Schreiber and Sarah Bingham. His father's grandfather, Johann Karl Schreiber emigrated from Swabia, Germany to England in the mid-18th century. His mother's father was rear admiral Joseph Bingham, and her grandfather was vice-admiral Sir William Parker, 1st Baronet, of Harburn.
* 31 October – Sir William Parker, 1st Baronet, of Harburn, admiral (born 1743)
#REDIRECT Sir William Parker, 1st Baronet, of Harburn
#REDIRECT Sir William Parker, 1st Baronet, of Harburn

The occupant of Radford in the 1881 and 1891 censuses was Thomas Bulteel (born 1838), a banker and a partner in the Naval Bank, formerly of 2 Wingfield Villas, Stoke Damerell, where he had resided in 1861 and 1871 with his family and six servants. His wife was Margaret Cork (born 1839). His eldest son was Percy Francis Bulteel (1865-1907), who married Julia Pine-Coffin, of that prominent family long seated at Portledge in the parish of Alwington, North Devon. Percy retired from partnership in "Harris, Bulteel & Co" (the Naval Bank) in 1898, when the bank had an undisclosed financial deficiency of £9,295See 1915 press report in Labour Voice below leaving just two partners remaining: his father Thomas Bulteel and a new partner to replace him, Mackworth Praed ParkerLondon Gazette, 1 Feb 1898, p.608 (1865-1926) of Moor Cross, Ivybridge, a grandson of Admiral of the Fleet Sir William Parker, 1st Baronet, of Harburn. From the date of Percy Bulteel's retirement the bank began to be operated recklessly which 16 years later led to its collapse and the destruction of the family's wealth (see below).
Admiral Sir William Parker, 1st Baronet, of Harburn died in 1802 at Beaufort House, which was his country estate when he was not living at 12 Crooms Hill, Greenwich.
